entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 16 of 31
entry.content:
Larry Bird was a great basketball player. Not because he was just a gifted athlete, but because of how he saw the game. It was said that he would map out the court and know where to be for the rebound. He would always be four or five moves ahead of the rest of the players.

What does this have to do with tonight's favorite thing? Play Rummikub, and you're forced to stay ahead of the game. Your current turn is the resultant execution of at least two turns' planning, along with anticipating each player's moves as well. You can't help but feel a thrill of excitement as strategy takes shape into action.

Try it. You'll like it.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 1 of 31
entry.content:
This is the stuff of legends; a true classic paired with the smooth taste of vanilla. It's not an addiction in the sense of the word, but I certainly can't help myself when I see it in restaurants. I also love that this tasty beverage pairs well even with the spiciest of Mexican foods, which is perfect, since it's found mostly in those locals.

Otherwise, it's hard to find the true formula. Officially discontinued in 2006, the Vanilla Coke found at your local supermarket is a second formula variety (released in 2007 under the moniker of Coca-Cola Vanilla) and while it does the trick in a pinch, to me it lacks the velvety nature of its fountain-variety brother.

Care to try it? Head to Rubio's. With any luck, you'll be sipping this sweet potation in no time at all.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 11 of 31
entry.content:
When Sumner got to be about a year old, I began to truly realize how blessed we were. We understood that the Lord knew Sumner would be the perfect child for us at that time, with me working longer hours at my job and Jenna looking forward to her 27 month long master's program.

What we needed was a companion; along for the ride of the long road ahead. Sumner has always been that for us, so smart and understanding of the world around him. I don't know if we could have accomplished what we did in our first few years of marriage with any other child.

Now, at almost eight years old, his little sisters know him mostly as "Buddy", because that's what he is.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 8 of 31
entry.content:
I took this picture of her over a year ago and fell in love with it immediately, and I knew I had to use it for my post tonight.

This little girl is an absolute joy; her smile leaves me in awe. I thought I was prepared for how hard she would tug at my heart, but as she gets older, the gravity well she emanates whenever I am away from her is almost too much to bear. But when we are reunited, her laughter fills my soul.

She will always be my baby girl. I love that she calls me her daddy. Like I said yesterday, there isn't a thing I wouldn't do for her.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 15 of 31
entry.content:
Jenna tells me that I associate special memories with places, rather than with people. It was an observation that I had never made myself; but it's true.

Enter Snowbird, a ski resort that holds not just a few memories of mine. When I was little, it was a place I went to with my entire family. Grandparents, parents, aunts, uncles, cousins, even some friends if I was lucky.

When I was in my early twenties, I worked there as a public safety officer (can you imagine?), and now that I have a family of my own, it's our own special place to visit whenever we're in Utah.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 9 of 31
entry.content:
Look. I'll eat pretty much any pizza, anywhere. Take n' bake, carry out, microwave, dine-in; it's hard to screw up pizza. But I still have a favorite, and that comes from Grimaldi's.

Tonight, we sat in close proximity to the prep area, and I gained an appreciation for why it tastes so amazing. Olive oil, fresh sliced mozzarella, basil, garlic, parmesan, and other ingredients were tossed about with precision. All of this on top a crust they prepare with PH balanced water that accurately mimics the h2o found in Brooklyn. Delicious each time.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 4 of 31
entry.content:
Jenna and I had the sweet occasion to attend the wedding of a couple of friends of mine this evening. Words heard during ceremonies always strike me; but tonight, one phrase in particular resonated a bit more.

It was the concept that together, you can accomplish anything. I think about our eight years of marriage together, and know that's true. So today, I present my ultimate favorite thing...my beautiful wife.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 2 of 31
entry.content:
My sophomore year of high school, I joined the cross country team. It was my own way of getting into shape for basketball season, but I fell in love with the sport.

I get pretty jealous watching my marathoner wife run with her friends and sister. See, I haven't been able to run much in the past eight years, only trying once or twice before giving into the whims of my left knee.

So, these shoes lay dormant. And before this past Monday, I thought they would stay that way. Following up with my doctor, he informed me that my meniscus looks fantastic, and as long as I come back to his office in three weeks with a strong leg and good movement, there's no reason why I can't start running again.

Best news I could have received after these many months of waiting.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 7 of 31
entry.content:
With songs such as Jackdaw, Gossamer Thread, Now and Always, and Please Forgive Me, I regret that more people don't know about David Gray. Then again, he doesn't get much radio play here in Phoenix, which definitely hurts his chances of acceptance.

The last opportunity I had to see him perform live in his signature three-piece suit was in September of 2010, when this picture was taken. It was a raucous show, full of energy and emotion, with hardly a pause or a chance to surface for air.

Many of you may be surprised to learn that he is my favorite artist; after all, hadn't I named my son after Sting? Indeed. But also keep in mind that I named my last daughter after Mr. Gray.

Anyone looking to dive into his music would be pleased with any of his works, although I recommend "Draw the Line" or "White Ladder" to start out.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 5 of 31
entry.content:
I don't remember when I first read it, or who actually introduced me to it. Over time, this book became a part of me. I identify with almost every character at some point in the story.

I have lent out and given more copies of this book than I can remember. In fact, I was surprised when I found an actual physical copy laying around my room.

Many people have a favorite book; what's yours?

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 6 of 31
entry.content:
The most poignant memories we make as human beings are commonly associated with the senses, with the most notable being our sense of smell. I can think of no better occasion for memories to come back into focus than Christmas time.

One holiday tradition I can clearly remember involves my dad making toffee for people. Every time he made it, the entire house carried this its aroma. After making several batches, I was the designated delivery boy. We would wind our way through the neighborhoods, dashing up to the doors, ringing the bells, stashing the goodies, and running back to the car. My parents were never ones for attention with this sort of thing.

The special recipe contains only four ingredients; butter, margarine, sugar, and chocolate to top it off. But as my dad taught me, it's the quantity and timing that count most.

So, this is kind of a double favorite; the memories revolving around this candy, and, now that I've grown, my love for making it for my friends and family.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 13 of 31
entry.content:
When the billowy monsoon clouds tumble over our Sonoran ranges, it's almost as if the sweltering months of summer are making a peace offering to the inhabitants of this land. This July, I had a different sentimentality pervade my thoughts, as I allowed my mind to drift downstream into the latter months of the year.

A cool December rain trumps all others. Now that it's truly here, I can see it for the contradiction it is during this stubbornly fevered time of year. In contrast to a summer rain, the winter storm tarries, never wanting to be in a hurry or rush to expire.

It is nature's dissension; a difference of opinion of the highest quality.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 10 of 31
entry.content:
OK, this is a pretty weird one. And it does show a bit of my quirky side; a side of me that exposes my obsessiveness.

Behold, the cup of Chips Ahoy! cookies. I love these things. Any more, I can't deal with regular Chips Ahoy! cookies, you know...the ones in the bags. They don't taste the same. No satisfaction. Wacky.

But ever since my friend Cristina gave me something like 10 cups of these for my birthday, I've been hooked. Major fan.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 12 of 31
entry.content: Sumner and I have been enjoying his Lego advent calendar this season. Yes, a few are already missing, most likely assimilated into the bucket of Legos we already have.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 14 of 31
entry.content:
I couldn't put pen to paper today, if you'll allow the expression. Between the three kids and other events that transpired today, it was a bit difficult to find creative time today.

Whenever I sat down to write, I felt that my words were too self-indulgent. The last thing I want from any of these posts is for them to come off as anything but sincere. But today's post does make me a bit sad, only because I don't get to play much anymore.

Oh, I'd reckon I'll shoot around again after the knee is strong, but soon, gone are the days of even half-court efforts.

I remember fondly those days and nights playing with my friends...heck, I'll name them here. To Sven, Neal, Eric, Jason, Jake, Ryan, Jordan, and the countless others, thanks for the games.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 17 of 31
entry.content: Life is a game of numbers. Volume, money, speed, age, temperature, it all comes down to the digits. And I have a peculiar affinity toward odd numbers, five being my favorite.

entry.title: What's this, then?
entry.content:
Greetings, travelers, and welcome to yet another blog by yours truly. If you've come here by way of The iPhone Photo Project, i hope you find this an entertaining diversion.
Here, you'll find a list catalogue of my favorite things. One for each day, ending the 31st of December. Like I said on Instagram, I am stealing Oprah's "Favorite Things" idea. Did I ever watch Oprah? Â Nah. But I loved the idea of getting to know someone better by learning about their treasures, vices, needs, and brand choices. So, this is a chance to get to know me.
Originally conceptualized as an Instagram-only adventure, I decided to post everything here as well.

entry.title: RD's Favorite Things - 3 of 31
entry.content:
Christmas of '87; I was a pretty lucky boy. I remember hoping and wishing for the Nintendo Entertainment System. Christmas morning, I ran downstairs with the family and quickly surveyed the scene, trying to see if any of the boxes under the tree matched the size and shape of the NES. Once opened, I was fixated on the next step; connecting it to our old downstairs television.

I can still remember watching my father and my eldest brother as they fiddled around with the RF Adaptor, gingerly screwing the two delicate connectors to the antenna connection, fine tuning the VHF and UHF dials until, ultimately, I saw that signature screen.

Super Mario Bros was the first game I played. I've been hooked on that signature platformer ever since.
